Dispute_Type: Contract and ownership dispute over yacht construction payments
Legal_Issue: Can F.C. Yachts Ltd. bring an action in rem against yachts it legally and beneficially owns?
Procedural_Stage: Motion to set aside warrant of arrest
Evidence_Assessment: Ownership confirmed via contract; Splash Holdings identified as mortgagee only
Decision_Outcome: Actions in rem dismissed; warrant of arrest set aside
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant (F.C. Yachts Ltd.) to establish right to in rem action
Legal_Rule: An action in rem requires the vessel to be beneficially owned by the party at the time the cause of action arose
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and application of procedural requirements
Procedural_Issue: Validity of arrest under in rem jurisdiction
Grounds_for_Claim: Unpaid progress payments for yacht construction
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed: F.C. Yachts cannot arrest its own vessels
Key_Evidence_Considered: Contract establishing ownership; absence of ownership transfer
Legal_Framework: Admiralty law, in rem actions, Federal Courts Act
Applicant_Challenge: F.C. Yachts' attempt to initiate in rem proceedings against its own property
Court_Result: Warrant of arrest set aside; costs awarded to Splash Holdings Ltd.
Defendant_Response: Splash Holdings moved to set aside the arrest, asserting lack of valid in rem basis
Remedy_Requested: Arrest of yachts through in rem action
Remedy_Sought: Enforcement of payment through maritime lien or arrest
Claimant_Status: F.C. Yachts Ltd. as legal and beneficial owner
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Lack of standing to bring in rem action against own vessels
Governing_Rule: Section 43(3), Federal Courts Act â€“ requirement of beneficial ownership for in rem actions
